description.summary: Norse female figures who choose who lives and dies in battle, serving Odin by selecting worthy warriors for Valhalla and serving mead in his hall.
description.full: Valkyries are female figures in Norse mythology who serve Odin, the Allfather. Their name means 'chooser of the slain' in Old Norse. They decide which warriors die in battle and which survive, then guide the slain heroes to Valhalla (Odin's hall) or Fólkvangr (Freyja's hall). Depicted as beautiful, armored female warriors who ride winged horses or wolves through the air, they also serve as handmaidens in Valhalla, bringing mead to the einherjar (chosen warriors) who prepare for Ragnarök. Valkyries are associated with swans and can transform into swan-maidens. Famous Valkyries include Brynhildr from the Völsunga saga, cursed by Odin for defying him.

Brynhildr story: Valkyrie cursed by Odin for disobedience
Opera popularizes Valkyries in modern culture with 'Ride of the Valkyries'

history.modern_era: Valkyries remain prominent in popular culture through Marvel Comics/MCU, fantasy literature, Viking-themed media, and as feminist warrior symbols. Wagner's 'Ride of the Valkyries' is one of the most recognized classical music pieces.

stories: Nine Valkyries named in various sagas
Valkyries weaving the fates of warriors (Darraðarljóð poem)
